sen.j: 豊国神社（ほうこくじんじゃ）は、滋賀県長浜市に鎮座する神社。
sen.e: Hokoku-jinja Shrine stands in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.
Hokoku-jinja Shrine stands in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.
Hokoku-jinja Shrine stands in Nagahama City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 「豊国大明神」こと豊臣秀吉のほか、事代主、加藤清正、木村重成を祭神とする。
sen.e: It enshrines Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, or "Hokoku Daimyojin (Great Luminous Deity of Our Bountiful Country)", as well as Kiyomasa KATO and Shigenari KIMURA as Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god).
It enshrines Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, or "Hokoku Daimyojin (Great Luminous Deity of Our Bountiful Country)", as well as Kiyomasa KATO and Shigenari KIMURA as Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god).
It enshrines Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, or "Hokoku Daimyojin (Great Luminous Deity of Our Bountiful Country)", as well as Kiyomasa KATO and Shigenari KIMURA as Kotoshiro nushi (a Japanese ancient god).

sen.j: 近江長浜6瓢箪巡りの第一番札所。
sen.e: It is the first fudasho (temples where amulets are distributed to pilgrims) in a pilgrimage of six temples in Omi-Nagahama.
sen.cmt: 文頭にウィキペディアより「近江長浜6瓢箪巡りの」を補いました。
sen.e: It is the first fudasho (temples where amulets are distributed to pilgrims) in a pilgrimage of six temples in Omi-Nagahama.
It is the first fudasho (temples where amulets are distributed to pilgrims) in a pilgrimage of six temples in Omi-Nagahama.
History
History
History

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉は天正元年（1573年）～天正4年（1576年）に長浜城 (近江国)主であった。
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI had been the lord of Nagahama Castle (Omi province) from 1573 to 1576.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI had been the lord of Nagahama-jo Castle (Omi Province) from 1573 to 1576.
sen.cmt: Nagahama Castle > Nagahama-jo CastleOmi province > Omi Province
sen.e: Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI had been the lord of Nagahama-jo Castle (Omi Province) from 1573 to 1576.

sen.j: 当社は長浜町民が、秀吉の3回忌に当たる慶長5年（1600年）、その遺徳を偲んで建立したものである。
sen.e: This shrine was constructed by Nagahama citizen remembering Hideyoshi's illustrious memory in 1600 at the second anniversary of his death.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This shrine was constructed by Nagahama citizen remembering Hideyoshi's illustrious memory in 1600 at the second anniversary of his death.
This shrine was constructed by Nagahama citizen remembering Hideyoshi's illustrious memory in 1600 at the second anniversary of his death.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、幕府の命により秀吉信仰が禁じられ、社殿も取り壊された。
sen.e: After the Edo period had started, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) placed the ban of Hideyoshi brief and pulled down the sanctuary, the main building of a Shinto shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the Edo period had started, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) placed the ban of Hideyoshi brief and pulled down the sanctuary, the main building of a Shinto shrine.
After the Edo period had started, the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) placed the ban of Hideyoshi brief and pulled down the sanctuary, the main building of a Shinto shrine.

sen.j: しかし、町民によって祭神は町年寄の家へ移され、その後、恵比須神を祀る神社の奥社で密かに祀っていた（現在の豊国神社で事代主が一緒に祀られているのはこのため）。
sen.e: While, the enshrined deity was moved to the house of machi-doshiyori (ward head) by citizens, then enshrined secretly in the back of a shrine for the Ebisu (a god of fishing and commerce), and that is why the Kotoshiro nushi is enshrined together in the present Hokoku-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: While, the enshrined deity was moved to the house of machi-doshiyori (ward head) by citizens, then enshrined secretly in the back of a shrine for the Ebisu (a god of fishing and commerce), and that is why the Kotoshiro nushi is enshrined together in the present Hokoku-jinja Shrine.

While, the enshrined deity was moved to the house of machi-doshiyori (ward head) by citizens, then enshrined secretly in the back of a shrine for the Ebisu (a god of fishing and commerce), and that is why the Kotoshiro nushi is enshrined together in the present Hokoku-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 明治維新後には「豊国神社」の名が復活し、秀吉の三百回忌に当たる明治31年（1898年）に拝殿が再建された。
sen.e: After the Maiji Restoration, the name of "Hokoku-jinja Shrine" revived and the haiden (a hall of worship) was reconstructed in 1898 at the 299th (or 300th by Japanese traditional way of counting ages) anniversary of Hideyoshi.

After the Maiji Restoration, the name of "Hokoku-jinja Shrine" revived and the haiden (a hall of worship) was reconstructed in 1898 at the 299th (or 300th by Japanese traditional way of counting ages) anniversary of Hideyoshi.

After the Maiji Restoration, the name of "Hokoku-jinja Shrine" revived and the haiden (a hall of worship) was reconstructed in 1898 at the 299th (or 300th by Japanese traditional way of counting ages) anniversary of Hideyoshi.

sen.j: 明治14年に村社、大正9年に郷社、大正11年に県社に列した。
sen.e: It was counted among the list of sonsha (a village shrine) in 1881, gosha (village shrine) in 1920, and prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) in 1922.
It was counted among the list of sonsha (a village shrine) in 1881, gosha (villages shrine) in 1920, and prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) in 1922.
sen.cmt: 村と郷の違いが分かりづらい為、郷の方はvillagesにしました。village > villages
sen.e: It was counted among the list of sonsha (a village shrine) in 1881, gosha (villages shrine) in 1920, and prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) in 1922.

sen.j: - 神殿は神明造、江戸時代中期築。
sen.e: The shinden (shrine sanctuary) was built in the style of Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) in the middle of the Edo period.
The shinden (shrine sanctuary) was built in the style of Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) in the middle of the Edo period.
The shinden (shrine sanctuary) was built in the style of Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) in the middle of the Edo period.
The kohai (a roof built over the steps leading up to a temple building) was built with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof), karahafu (cusped gable).
The kohai (a roof built over the steps leading up to a temple building) was built with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof), karahafu (cusped gable).
The kohai (a roof built over the steps leading up to a temple building) was built with hiwadabuki (cypress bark roof), karahafu (cusped gable).
The haiden (a hall of worship) was built with chidori hafu (a trianglular shaped gable or a dormer bargeboard, or both combined).
